ğŸ›The teeny, tiniest little gestures go a long way. Before heading into the weekend, I wanted to share these quick thoughts. LinkedIn can be a lonely place for a job seeker or someone struggling professionally. However, itâ€™s also a great place to put a little love out there. Here are a few ways to show some love on LinkedIn. None of these gestures need to take more than one minute. Endorse a skill on someone's profile. Write a recommendation for a colleague or connection. These can be incredibly helpful when they are looking for their next job. Comment positively on someone's post. Comments are currently the gold standard of social engagement, so take a few extra seconds after slamming that like button. Thank someone publicly for their help or mentorship. Send a personalized connection request with a note. Engage with a company post you admire or support. Share a success story about a project or collaboration. Participate in a LinkedIn group discussion related to your field. Post a shoutout to a colleague or connection for their work. Offer to help someone with a job search or career advice. Congratulate someone on a work anniversary. Recommend a book or resource that you found valuable. Introduce two connections who could benefit from knowing each other. Share your professional milestones with gratitude to those who helped you along the way. Send a thank-you message after a meeting or event. Many times, tons of work goes into organizing events! Highlight a team achievement or project success. To amp it up, tag individuals with thoughtful notes on their unique impact. Share a testimonial about a product or service you used. Express appreciation for someone's post or content. Update your profile to reflect recent achievements. Engage with posts from industry leaders and influencers. Reach down the ladder. Offer to mentor someone in your field. Share positive feedback from clients or customers. How do you show kindness to your colleagues, friends, or even your boss? I'd love to know! And...if you like this post, join my weekly newsletter, Getting There, for more like this! The link is in the comments!

Hi there, I'm back to talk about...talking. Specifically, I want to dip back into meaningful career conversations to initiate at work. The third conversation (after exploring your career path and values) is about your expectations. ğŸ“° What to Talk About: Talk about the future. Specifically, address what your goals may be, how your company can empower you to reach them, and what "it means" to achieve successâ€”both from your perspective and the perspective of your organization. ğŸ—£ï¸ Who to Speak to: This is one of those conversations that you should make time to have with your boss or manager. ğŸŒ What to Explore: This is one of those career conversations you can have at a macro- and micro-level. Macro Expectations at Work â€¢What do we know about the history of my role? What did other employees manage or achieve optimally in this role? â€¢What will a successful first year look like for someone in this role? â€¢What are the three main priorities for this role? Micro Expectations at Work â€¢What is the goal of this specific project? â€¢What impact is my contribution expected to make? â€¢How will I know I was successful in this meeting/on this phone call/in completing this project? â“Why This Conversation: If you have this conversation when starting a role, you can set your career expectations early. You can cooperatively understand the "why" in all efforts by speaking with your boss or manager. Like many of these career conversations, use this talk to open yourself up to future conversations about expectationsâ€”especially when adjusting or modifying them. Stay tuned for more important career conversations, or find a link to the full guide to career conversations in the first comment! #careerconversations #professionaldevelopment
